Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Groundwork for developing multiscale modeling studies of thermoelectric materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
The majority of energy produced through the combustion of gasoline in an automobile is lost as waste heat. Through the use of thermoelectric materials, effectively converting waste heat into electrical power, the lost energy can be recovered. Optimizing and manufacturing thermoelectric materials poses a big challenge due to the lack of knowledge of structural control and thermal-to-electrical conversion efficiency. Computational modeling plays an important role to explore the underlying science and ease this challenge. The project will investigate how structural features and dopants affect thermoelectric properties of thermoelectric materiala. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Prof. Jin Zhao and Prof. Jinlong Yang, the experts in first-principles quantum mechanical method and thermoelectric materials, at the University of Science and Technology of China in Hefei, China.

The project will study the structural features of thermoelectric materials, specifically various filled skutterudite compounds-a promising candidate, and determine structural effects on thermoelectric properties. Density functional theory-based approaches will be used to perform the structural, electronic, and phonon calculations. This research will lay the foundation for the development of a multiscale modeling framework for characterizing and optimizing thermoelectric materials. Based on the research results, two computational modeling case studies will also be developed, which can be integrated into materials science and engineering curriculum. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The majority of energy produced through gasoline combustion in an automobile is lost as waste heat. A portion of this energy can be recovered through the use of thermoelectric materials which can convert waste heat into electrical power. Thermoelectric performance is measured by a dimensionless figure of merit, ZT = S2σT/κ where S is the Seebeck coefficient and σ and κ are the electrical and thermal conductivities, respectively, at a given temperature T. For a high ZT value (ZT > 1), a thermoelectric material is required to have high S and σ but low κ. Optimizing these three parameters can be achieved by identifying novel thermoelectric materials or doping existing materials with other species. However, controlling the structure and improving the thermal-to-electrical conversion efficiency remains a challenge. Computational modeling can ease these challenges by exploring underlying science and guiding production.

To facilitate the development of a computational model, a series of geometric, electronic, and phonon calculations were conducted on various skutterudite and MX2 compounds through first-principles using density functional theory (DFT). The effects of doping and material composition on the structural features (unit cell size, atomic bond lengths and angles, cell volume) were investigated. The electronic properties were determined through density of states (DOS) and band structure calculations which can be used with the BoltzTraP software code to calculate semi-classic transport coefficients such as S and σ/τ where τ is the phonon relaxation time. The thermal properties were investigated through phonon dispersion calculations which, in conjunction with the Boltzmann Transport Equations (BTE), can be utilized to calculate lattice thermal conductivity. The end result of this project would be the development of a full bottom-up approach for modeling thermoelectric phenomena of a given material. This model could then be used to design or optimize experiments and lead to the development of high-performance, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly thermoelectric materials.
